nexttext:
In what follows the first-nearest-neighbor approximation for the exchange interaction is used. $G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma}$, $G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma}$ are related to Green's function of the background state: a N\'{e}el antiferromagnetic state if $R_f \ne 0$, a paramagnetic state if $R_f = 0$, and satisfied the following equations:
\begin{eqnarray}
\left( i\omega_n - \xi_{\text{L} \sigma} - F_{0\sigma}a_{p} \right) G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) & - & F_{0\sigma}b_p G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) = F_{0 \sigma},
\\
\left( i\omega_n - \xi_{\text{L} \bar{\sigma}} - F_{0\bar{\sigma}}a_{p} \right) G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) & - & F_{0\bar{\sigma}}b_p G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) = 0.
\end{eqnarray}
For simplicity we take into account only intra-sublattice hybridization~$V_{\vec{p}}$, then
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta_{\vec{p}}=\frac{T}{N}\sum_{k\sigma}\frac{J_{\vec{p}-\vec{k}}}{2}\eta_{%
\sigma}F_{GF\sigma}^{{\dagger}}\left(k\right)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>T</mi><mi>N</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>J</mi><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>η</mi><mi>σ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
In what follows the first-nearest-neighbor approximation for the exchange interaction is used. $G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma}$, $G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma}$ are related to Green's function of the background state: a N\'{e}el antiferromagnetic state if $R_f \ne 0$, a paramagnetic state if $R_f = 0$, and satisfied the following equations:
\begin{eqnarray}
\left( i\omega_n - \xi_{\text{L} \sigma} - F_{0\sigma}a_{p} \right) G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) & - & F_{0\sigma}b_p G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) = F_{0 \sigma},
\\
\left( i\omega_n - \xi_{\text{L} \bar{\sigma}} - F_{0\bar{\sigma}}a_{p} \right) G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) & - & F_{0\bar{\sigma}}b_p G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma} \left( p \right) = 0.
\end{eqnarray}
For simplicity we take into account only intra-sublattice hybridization~$V_{\vec{p}}$, then
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="a_{p}=\frac{\left(i\omega_{n}-\xi_{\text{c}\vec{p}}\right)|V_{\vec{p}}|^{2}}{%
\left(i\omega_{n}-\xi_{\text{c}\vec{p}}\right)^{2}-\Gamma_{\vec{p}}^{2}},\,\,%
\,b_{p}=\frac{\Gamma_{\vec{p}}|V_{\vec{p}}|^{2}}{\left(i\omega_{n}-\xi_{\text{%
c}\vec{p}}\right)^{2}-\Gamma_{\vec{p}}^{2}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo rspace="7.6pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The summation on $\delta_x$, $\delta_y$ are carried over nearest sites along $x$ axis and $y$ axis, respectively. In real space GL equation can be obtained after taking a continuum limit for slowly varying $\Delta_f$, $R_f$.

The difference between the GL coefficients $\gamma_{1}$ and $\gamma_{2}$ is connected with the fact that Cooper instability doesn't change much the antiferromagnetic order parameter in the SC+AFM phase as it has been shown in~\cite{VVV-12}. Otherwise the antiferromagnetic ordering has a particularly strong influence on the superconducting order parameter. Therefore the term with~$\gamma_{2}$ in equation~(\ref{GL_Eq_2}) can be neglected.

It should be noted that equations~(\ref{GL_Eq_1}), (\ref{GL_Eq_2}) for non-zero $\Delta_f, R_f$ are valid only near a critical temperature $T_{\mbox{co}}$ of the SC+AFM phase. It means that the  N\'{e}el temperature $T_{\mbox{N}}$ should be close to the onset temperature of superconductivity $T_{\mbox{c}}$. We assume that $T_{\mbox{N}} > T_{\mbox{c}}$ which is a case of rare-earth heavy-fermion superconductors such as CeCu$_2$Si$_2$, CeIn$_3$, CeRhIn$_5$.

The temperature dependence of superconducting order parameter in this assumption is described by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta_{f}=\sum_{\delta_{x}}\Delta_{f,f+\delta_{x}}-\sum_{\delta_{y}}\Delta_{f%
,f+\delta_{y}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></munder><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></munder><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $\alpha_s(T) = \alpha^{'}_s \left( T - T_{\mbox{c}} \right)$, $\alpha_m(T) = \alpha^{'}_m \left( T - T_{\mbox{N}} \right)$ and
prevtext:
The summation on $\delta_x$, $\delta_y$ are carried over nearest sites along $x$ axis and $y$ axis, respectively. In real space GL equation can be obtained after taking a continuum limit for slowly varying $\Delta_f$, $R_f$.

The difference between the GL coefficients $\gamma_{1}$ and $\gamma_{2}$ is connected with the fact that Cooper instability doesn't change much the antiferromagnetic order parameter in the SC+AFM phase as it has been shown in~\cite{VVV-12}. Otherwise the antiferromagnetic ordering has a particularly strong influence on the superconducting order parameter. Therefore the term with~$\gamma_{2}$ in equation~(\ref{GL_Eq_2}) can be neglected.

It should be noted that equations~(\ref{GL_Eq_1}), (\ref{GL_Eq_2}) for non-zero $\Delta_f, R_f$ are valid only near a critical temperature $T_{\mbox{co}}$ of the SC+AFM phase. It means that the  N\'{e}el temperature $T_{\mbox{N}}$ should be close to the onset temperature of superconductivity $T_{\mbox{c}}$. We assume that $T_{\mbox{N}} > T_{\mbox{c}}$ which is a case of rare-earth heavy-fermion superconductors such as CeCu$_2$Si$_2$, CeIn$_3$, CeRhIn$_5$.

The temperature dependence of superconducting order parameter in this assumption is described by

nexttext: When the antiferromagnetic order parameter is rather small near the critical temperature $T_{\mbox{co}}$, it is possible to expand the Green's functions $G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma}$, $G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma}$ into series in terms of $R_f$. Solving the system equations~(\ref{G_Eq}), (\ref{F_Eq}) by iterations in the SC+AFM phase microscopic expressions for the GL coefficients have been found:
prevtext: where $\alpha_s(T) = \alpha^{'}_s \left( T - T_{\mbox{c}} \right)$, $\alpha_m(T) = \alpha^{'}_m \left( T - T_{\mbox{N}} \right)$ and

nexttext:
where $F_0$ is a Hubbard renormalization and $G_0^{(FF)}$, $G_0^{(GF)}$ are Green's functions in the paramagnetic phase, $\phi_{\text{d}}$ --- d-wave basis function.
\begin{eqnarray}
\beta_s =  \frac{T}{N}\frac{16J}{F_0^6} \sum_{k} \phi_{\text{d}}^4(\vec{k})\left\{ \left[ G_0^{(FF)}(-k)G_0^{(FF)}(k) + G_0^{(GF)}(-k)G_0^{(GF)}(k) \right]^2 + \right.
\nonumber \\
\left. + \left[ G_0^{(FF)}(-k)G_0^{(GF)}(k) + G_0^{(GF)}(-k)G_0^{(FF)}(k) \right]^2 \right\}.
\end{eqnarray}
It is more convenient to represent the GL coefficients connected with antiferromagnetic ordering in the transformed form:
prevtext: When the antiferromagnetic order parameter is rather small near the critical temperature $T_{\mbox{co}}$, it is possible to expand the Green's functions $G^{(FF)}_{A \sigma}$, $G^{(GF)}_{A \sigma}$ into series in terms of $R_f$. Solving the system equations~(\ref{G_Eq}), (\ref{F_Eq}) by iterations in the SC+AFM phase microscopic expressions for the GL coefficients have been found:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\alpha_{s}\left(T\right)=1-\frac{T}{N}\frac{4J}{F_{0}^{2}}\sum_{k}\phi_{\text{%
d}}^{2}(\vec{k})\left[G_{0}^{(FF)}(-k)G_{0}^{(FF)}(k)+G_{0}^{(GF)}(-k)G_{0}^{(%
GF)}(k)\right]," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>T</mi><mi>N</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>J</mi></mrow><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>k</mi></munder><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϕ</mi><mtext>d</mtext><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $F_0$ is a Hubbard renormalization and $G_0^{(FF)}$, $G_0^{(GF)}$ are Green's functions in the paramagnetic phase, $\phi_{\text{d}}$ --- d-wave basis function.
\begin{eqnarray}
\beta_s =  \frac{T}{N}\frac{16J}{F_0^6} \sum_{k} \phi_{\text{d}}^4(\vec{k})\left\{ \left[ G_0^{(FF)}(-k)G_0^{(FF)}(k) + G_0^{(GF)}(-k)G_0^{(GF)}(k) \right]^2 + \right.
\nonumber \\
\left. + \left[ G_0^{(FF)}(-k)G_0^{(GF)}(k) + G_0^{(GF)}(-k)G_0^{(FF)}(k) \right]^2 \right\}.
\end{eqnarray}
It is more convenient to represent the GL coefficients connected with antiferromagnetic ordering in the transformed form:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\alpha_{m}\left(T\right)=1-\frac{T}{N}\sum_{k}c\left(k\right),\,\,\,c\left(k%
\right)=\frac{\left(i\omega_{n}-\xi_{\text{L}}-2F_{0}J\right)\left[\left(i%
\omega_{n}-\xi_{\text{c}\vec{k}}\right)^{2}-\Gamma_{\vec{k}}^{2}\right]}{\prod%
\limits_{i}\left(i\omega_{n}-E_{i\vec{k}}^{(0)}\right)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>T</mi><mi>N</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>k</mi></munder><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.6pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>J</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>
